pageData.text: Although cells are 70–95% water, the rest consists mostly of carbon-based compounds, which are also known as organic compounds. Carbon is unparalleled in its ability to form large, complex, and diverse molecules. There is an enormous assemblage of organic molecules synthesized and used by living things referred to as biological macromolecules. These biological macromolecules can be divided into four categories: , , , and . This lab introduces the framework of biological macromolecules. This framework consist predominantly of carbon atoms bonded to each other or to other atoms. Molecular models will be used to explore the chemistry of carbon and to build the macromolecules that comprise all living organisms. The basic structures of the four groups of biological compounds will be examined. Finally, the process through which of sugars and amino acids combine to form will be modeled.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation – 10 minutes 
Activity 1: Hydrocarbons – 15 minutes 
Activity 2: Carbohydrates – 30 minutes 
Activity 3: Lipids – 30 minutes 
Activity 4: Protein – 15 minutes 
Activity 5: Nucleic Acids – 25 minutes 
Disposal and Cleanup – 5 minutes

text: Describe the relationship between functional groups and macromolecules.
Explain how macromolecules are assembled and disassembled putting this into context with the four categories of biological macromolecules.
For each category of biological macromolecule, describe the basic structures; how those structures relate to larger, more complex molecules; and give examples of each category and their functions.
Construct and be able to identify models of biological macromolecules.

pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.subTitle: Protocol symbols
pageData.altText: video link symbol, camera symbol, stopwatch symbol

pageData.subTitle: Hazard pictograms
pageData.altText: warning symbol, corrosion symbol, flammable symbol, toxic symbol, environment symbol, health hazard symbol

pageData.text: It seems like every year new “fad diets” are advertised. In 1918, the first U.S. fad diet book was published by Lulu Hunt Peters, “Diet & Health: With Key to the Calories”. She suggested that it didn’t matter what a person ate, as long as they only consumed the number of calories that was appropriate for their height. And if the recommended calorie amount was followed, then a person could lose weight. However, it is now understood that eating a balanced diet and maintaining an active lifestyle is an integral part of weight loss.

Eating a balanced diet is important and provides the nutrients that your body needs to function effectively. A balanced diet strengthens the immune system and helps protect against communicable and chronic non-communicable diseases. Recently, the USDA introduced the food plate, modified from the food pyramid, to help people remember that everyone needs a balance of fruits, vegetables, grains, , and smaller amounts of oils and dairy products. Rather than following a strict “diet” they recommend that everyone consume a variety of grains, fruits, and vegetables and limit the amount of saturated fat, sugar, and salt.

pageData.altText: The USDA food plate diagram from myplate.gov.
pageData.desc: The USDA food plate diagram from myplate.gov.

pageData.text: Life at the cellular level is based on the production of large molecules called macromolecules. Macromolecules consist of smaller units known as (derived from the Greek word meaning one part). Macromolecules are also called (derived from the Greek word meaning many parts), because they are created by linking multiple monomers. Polymers may consist of identical monomers, similar to the links in a chain, or they may be composed of different monomers, similar to the beads in a multicolored bracelet. The process of joining monomers to form a polymer is called . Macromolecules are created by joining monomers through a process called dehydration, which is the removal of a water molecule. There are four main groups of macromolecules found in all living organisms: , , , and .

Carbohydrates, lipids, nucleic acids, and proteins have chemically reactive sites called functional groups. Functional groups contain a recognizable subset of atoms within a larger molecule and are responsible for characteristic chemical reactions. The three functional groups that are commonly found in carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, and nucleic acids are:

The term “carbon-based life-form” is an accurate description of a living organism at the molecular level. Molecules in all living organisms primarily consist of chains of carbon atoms attached to hydrogen, oxygen, and nitrogen atoms. In fact, 96% of the mass of a human body is composed of these four elements. Most of the mass (about 53%) of a human body is due to water (H<sub>2</sub>O). <button class='glossary-text'>Hydrocarbons</button> are the second most common type of compound. Hydrocarbons contain carbon and hydrogen. Three characteristics make carbon one of the best elements for forming long, complex molecules.
Carbon has four valence (outer-shell) electrons that can be shared with valence electrons of other elements (Figure 1).

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Figure of the valances in carbon

pageData.text: The valence electrons of a carbon atom can be shared with other carbon atoms. In a , each atom contributes one electron. Thus, the two atoms share a pair of electrons and form a molecule. Each carbon atom must have four covalent bonds to have a complete valence shell of eight electrons (Figure 2).

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Figure of methane, Figure of propane

pageData.text: Carbon atoms can form chains or rings composed of single, double, and triple . Carbon atoms can bond with other carbon atoms or with atoms of different elements; several examples are shown in Figure 3. Molecular formulas show the kind and number of atoms but not their arrangement. In a structural formula, each dash represents a covalent chemical bond.
Ethyne is a systematic name, in which the suffix “-yne” indicates the presence of a triple bond. In biology, ethyne is often referred to by its common name, acetylene.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Figure of ethene, Figure of acetylene, Figure of benzene, Figure of acetic acid

pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>Hydrocarbons</button> activity demonstrates how a carbon atom forms covalent bonds with carbon and hydrogen atoms to produce chains and ring-shaped structures known as hydrocarbons. These carbon bonds are essential for the production of macromolecules in living systems.

pageData.question: The majority of the human body is made up of which of the following sets of atomic elements?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: 96% of the human body is made up of carbon, hydrogen, oxygen, and nitrogen.

pageData.question: There are several characteristics of carbon that make it an ideal element for forming long, complex molecules. Which of the following properties of carbon is true?

options.text: Carbon can form four covalent bonds.
Carbon can form double bonds but not triple bonds.
Carbon can only bond to hydrogen atoms.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Carbon contains four electrons in its valence shell and will form four covalent bonds with other atoms to achieve stability. This allows carbon-rich organic molecules to form stable chain or ring structures.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
The term “carbon-based life-form” is an accurate description of a living organism at the molecular level. Molecules in all living organisms primarily consist of chains of carbon atoms attached to hydrogen, oxygen, and nitrogen atoms. In fact, 96% of the mass of a human body is composed of these four elements. Most of the mass of a human body is due to water first, and hydrocarbons second. Hydrocarbons contain carbon and hydrogen. Three characteristics make carbon one of the best elements for forming long, complex molecules:
  1. Carbon has four valence (outer-shell) electrons that can be shared with valence electrons of other elements.
  2. The valence electrons of a carbon atom can be shared with other carbon atoms. In a covalent bond, each atom contributes one electron. Thus, the two atoms share a pair of electrons and form a molecule. Each carbon atom must have four covalent bonds to have a complete valence shell of eight electrons.
  3. Carbon atoms can form chains or rings composed of single, double, and triple covalent bonds. Carbon atoms can bond with other carbon atoms or with atoms of different elements.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
The term “carbon-based life-form” is an accurate description of a living organism at the molecular level. Molecules in all living organisms primarily consist of chains of carbon atoms attached to hydrogen, oxygen, and nitrogen atoms. In fact, 96% of the mass of a human body is composed of these four elements. Most of the mass of a human body is due to water first, and hydrocarbons second. Hydrocarbons contain carbon and hydrogen. Three characteristics make carbon one of the best elements for forming long, complex molecules:
  1. Carbon has four valence (outer-shell) electrons that can be shared with valence electrons of other elements.
  2. The valence electrons of a carbon atom can be shared with other carbon atoms. In a covalent bond, each atom contributes one electron. Thus, the two atoms share a pair of electrons and form a molecule. Each carbon atom must have four covalent bonds to have a complete valence shell of eight electrons.
  3. Carbon atoms can form chains or rings composed of single, double, and triple covalent bonds. Carbon atoms can bond with other carbon atoms or with atoms of different elements.

pageData.subTitle: Carbohydrates
pageData.text: Each <button class='glossary-text'>carbohydrate</button> has an empirical formula (simplest whole-number ratio of atoms) of CH<sub>2</sub>O, which indicates a ratio of 1:2:1 for carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen, respectively. Think of a carbohydrate as a “Carbon-Hydrate” or a carbon plus a water molecule. In the simplest terms, photosynthesis combines CO<sub>2</sub> and H<sub>2</sub>O to form O<sub>2</sub> and CH<sub>2</sub>O, a carbohydrate.

Carbohydrates are compounds that serve as sources of energy at the cellular level. In plants and some animals, carbohydrates also provide structural materials. Oxidation of the simple sugar glucose (C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>12</sub>O<sub>6</sub>) is the most common source of immediate energy for cellular metabolism.

C5H12O6 + 6O2     6CO2 + 6H2O + energy
                   Oxidation of Glucose

In the simplest terms, a carbohydrate reacts with oxygen, O2, to produce CO2 and H2O (and energy). Another name for a single-sugar molecule is . In addition to glucose, fructose and galactose are monosaccharides.

Carbohydrates contain oxygen, hydrogen, and carbon. The saccharides are an important group of carbohydrates. Oxygen binds to hydrogen and forms a hydroxyl group (–OH), which is commonly found in carbohydrates. Hydroxyl groups tend to act as important reactive groups in many chemical reactions.

Crystalline glucose has an open-chain structure. However, glucose in biological systems usually exists in a cyclic or “ring” form. This is because the ends of the glucose molecule come together, such that the oxygen that has a double bond with carbon #1 reacts with the –OH group that is attached to carbon #5.

If are not immediately used for energy, they can be stored in multi-chained known as . Animals store simple sugars as a polysaccharide called glycogen, which can be found in the liver. When glucose levels drop in the bloodstream, glycogen is released from the liver and converted into glucose. Starches or “complex ” are the most common types of polysaccharide energy storage in plants. The polysaccharide cellulose is manufactured to provide tough fibers for cell walls. The strength of cellulose enables trees to grow to great heights and supports heavy weights.

pageData.question: Which of the following is one function of carbohydrates in living organisms?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Carbohydrates can form complex polymers for storing thousands of monosaccharides, the preferred substrate for cellular respiration which provides cells with energy.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the structure of complex carbohydrates such as glycogen, an energy-storage molecule produced by animals?

options.text: many simple sugar molecules linked together
two simple sugar molecules linked together
many simple sugar molecules surrounded by a membrane

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Complex carbohydrates, or polysaccharides, are made up of many simple sugar molecules, or monosaccharides, linked together in long chains or branched structures.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Carbohydrates consist of sugar molecules, such as glucose, as their basic unit. They are produced by photosynthesis in plants and are the preferred substrate for cellular respiration in living organisms. Because sugar molecules are the preferred source of energy, organisms evolved biochemical pathways for linking multiple sugars together to form complex carbohydrates, which store sugar molecules more compactly until they are ready to be used (Figure 4). In organisms that lack internal skeletal systems (such as plants, fungi and insects) complex carbohydrates also serve as structural molecules, providing rigidity to cell walls or exoskeletons, and therefore overall structural support to these groups of organisms.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Carbohydrates consist of sugar molecules, such as glucose, as their basic unit. They are produced by photosynthesis in plants and are the preferred substrate for cellular respiration in living organisms. Because sugar molecules are the preferred source of energy, organisms evolved biochemical pathways for linking multiple sugars together to form complex carbohydrates, which store sugar molecules more compactly until they are ready to be used (Figure 4). In organisms that lack internal skeletal systems (such as plants, fungi and insects) complex carbohydrates also serve as structural molecules, providing rigidity to cell walls or exoskeletons, and therefore overall structural support to these groups of organisms.

pageData.subTitle: Lipids
pageData.text: are a group of macromolecules composed of carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen and are usually insoluble in water. One function of a lipid is to store energy long-term, yielding twice as many calories per gram as that of a . are common lipids in plants and animals. The name refers to three fatty acids joined to an alcohol known as glycerol. The presence of a carboxyl group (–COOH) in an organic compound indicates that the compound is an organic acid. Fatty acids consist of a single carboxyl group attached to long chains.

Naturally occurring fatty acids have even numbers of carbon atoms, are straight-chained, and are either saturated or unsaturated. A chain is composed entirely of carbon atoms joined by single . An has one double bond in its carbon chain (two fewer hydrogen atoms). A hydrogen atom is removed from each carbon involved in the double bond of a fatty acid. The removal of hydrogen is called . A has two or more double bonds in its carbon chain (four, six, etc., fewer hydrogen atoms).

Unsaturated fatty acids include carbons joined by one or more double bonds. In this type of fatty acid, double bonds limit the number of hydrogen atoms attached to the carbon chain. The double bonds also cause “kinks” to form in the long chain of carbon atoms that cannot be straightened. Saturated fatty-acid chains have only carbon-carbon single bonds and are more flexible. The carbon chains are straight, so the three fatty acids can be pushed closer to one another. Because of this, triglycerides with saturated fatty acids tend to form solids at much lower temperatures. Saturated fatty acids are frequently solids at room temperature. The double bonds of unsaturated fatty acids cause the chain to bend and take up more space. Unsaturated fatty acids are usually liquids at room temperature. Triglycerides with saturated fatty acids are usually referred to as fats, whereas unsaturated triglycerides are called oils. Animals usually store lipids as saturated fats, whereas plants tend to store lipids as unsaturated oils. Common oils, such as corn, coconut, and palm oils, are triglycerides that contain mostly unsaturated fatty acids.

The family of lipids also includes phospholipids, the predominant molecules in the plasma membrane of a cell, and cholesterol, which is also a component of the plasma membrane and a precursor of steroid hormones. Other important lipids are steroids, waxes, and some vitamins. Cholesterol is a steroid that is associated with animal fats, especially saturated fats. Lipoproteins are complex compounds formed from lipids and . Vitamins A, D, E, and K are lipids.

pageData.question: One of the most common lipids in plants and animals is triglyceride. Although triglycerides vary somewhat in their structure, they all have the same basic structure. Which of the following best describes the structure of a triglyceride?

options.text: three fatty acids attached to an alcohol molecule
three glycerol molecules attached to a saturated fatty acid chain
an alcohol molecule attached to a three-carbon fatty acid chain
a fatty acid attached to three alcohol molecules
three fatty acid rings attached to a central glycerol molecule

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: As the name suggests, in a triglyceride three fatty acid chains are attached to one glycerol, which is an alcohol.

pageData.question: The term “hydrogenated oil” is one that you have likely seen on food packaging or heard about in the news. It is a type of fat that food manufacturers developed by adding hydrogen atoms to unsaturated fat. Based on what you know about lipids, which of the following best describes a hydrogenated oil?

options.text: A solid fat that resembles naturally occurring saturated fat.
A liquid fat that is soluble in water.
A liquid fat that is carbonated with hydrogen gas.
A solid fat with a high melting point.
A fat that is gaseous at room temperature.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Hydrogenated oils are unsaturated fats that have been modified by the addition of hydrogen atoms, which removes the double bonds in the fatty acid chains and changes them from unsaturated to saturated fatty acids. Hydrogenated oils are made from liquid vegetable oils but have a semi-solid or solid consistency.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: There are many different types of triglycerides found in plants and animals. Based on the structure of the fatty acid chains in a triglyceride, the molecule will perform different functions and have different chemical properties. However, all triglycerides have the same basic structure. Glycerol, a type of alcohol (shown here in black), is bonded to three fatty acid chains. These chains can be saturated or unsaturated, but this basic structure remains the same. Saturated fatty acids are hydrocarbon chains with no double bonds; they are “saturated” with hydrogen atoms. Unsaturated fatty acids are hydrocarbon chains with one more double bonds. The straight chain structure of saturated fatty acids means saturated fat molecules stack on each other easily, forming solids at room temperature. In contrast, unsaturated fatty acids are not straight chains and are liquid at room temperature.

img.alt: The chemical structure of a triglyceride molecule.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: There are many different types of triglycerides found in plants and animals. Based on the structure of the fatty acid chains in a triglyceride, the molecule will perform different functions and have different chemical properties. However, all triglycerides have the same basic structure. Glycerol, a type of alcohol (shown here in black), is bonded to three fatty acid chains. These chains can be saturated or unsaturated, but this basic structure remains the same. Saturated fatty acids are hydrocarbon chains with no double bonds; they are “saturated” with hydrogen atoms. Unsaturated fatty acids are hydrocarbon chains with one more double bonds. The straight chain structure of saturated fatty acids means saturated fat molecules stack on each other easily, forming solids at room temperature. In contrast, unsaturated fatty acids are not straight chains and are liquid at room temperature.

img.alt: The chemical structure of a triglyceride molecule.

pageData.subTitle: Proteins
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Proteins</button> are among the most complex organic compounds. The building blocks of a protein are amino acids. Proteins differ greatly from one another due to the number, kind, and arrangement of amino acids. The molecular shape and distribution of electrical charges are important features of proteins and affect their individual roles in biological processes. Proteins form complexes with other organic molecules and are basic functional and structural components of all living systems.

Proteins are large with diverse functions, including structural support and movement. Enzymes are specialized proteins that increase the rate of chemical reactions. Each protein has a unique shape that affects its function. Although there are thousands of proteins, each is formed from among twenty different called amino acids. All amino acids have a basic structure consisting of a carboxyl group (–COOH) and an amino group (–NH2) attached to a central carbon atom as shown in Figure 5.

pageData.altText: Figure 5: Structure of an amino acid

pageData.text: Amino acids differ from one another at their R group, which is a side chain that is attached to the central carbon. The R group varies from a single hydrogen atom to a long carbon chain. Two amino acids are joined by a dehydration reaction, in which a hydrogen atom is removed from an amino group on one molecule, and a hydroxyl group (–OH) is removed from the carboxylic-acid end of the other molecule to form water, H2O, as shown in Figure 6. This reaction results in the formation of a , which joins two amino acids to form a dipeptide. Multiple peptide units can be linked to form longer peptide chains called polypeptides. A consists of one or more polypeptide chains, which are folded and coiled into a specific shape.

pageData.altText: Figure 6: Two amino acids joined together

pageData.question: Which of the following components of an amino acid is variable in structure and defines the overall chemical properties of a particular amino acid?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: All amino acids have an amino group and a carboxyl group, both of which are attached to a central carbon. All amino acids also have an R group, which differs in structure for each type of amino acid.

pageData.question: Proteins perform a variety of functions in living organisms, such as providing structure or catalyzing chemical reactions. Which of the following properties of a protein is most critical to the function it performs?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: It is the shape of each protein that allows it to perform a specific function. Environmental conditions that affect the way a protein is folded, and therefore its shape, can affect the function of that protein.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Proteins are large polymers with diverse functions, including structural support and movement. Each protein has a unique shape that affects its function. Although there are thousands of proteins, each is formed from among twenty different monomers called amino acids. All amino acids have a basic structure consisting of a carboxyl group (–COOH) and an amino group (–NH<sub>2</sub>) attached to a central carbon atom, as shown in Figure 5.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>Amino acids differ from one another at their R group, which is a side chain that is attached to the central carbon. The R group varies from a single hydrogen atom to a long carbon chain. Two amino acids are joined by a dehydration reaction, in which a hydrogen atom is removed from an amino group on one molecule, and a hydroxyl group (–OH) is removed from the carboxylic-acid end of the other molecule to form water, H<sub>2</sub>O. This reaction results in the formation of a peptide bond, which joins two amino acids to form a dipeptide. Multiple peptide units can be linked to form longer peptide chains called polypeptides. A protein consists of one or more polypeptide chains, which are folded and coiled into a specific shape.

img.alt: Figure 5: Structure of an amino acid

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Proteins are large polymers with diverse functions, including structural support and movement. Each protein has a unique shape that affects its function. Although there are thousands of proteins, each is formed from among twenty different monomers called amino acids. All amino acids have a basic structure consisting of a carboxyl group (–COOH) and an amino group (–NH2) attached to a central carbon atom, as shown in Figure 5.Amino acids differ from one another at their R group, which is a side chain that is attached to the central carbon. The R group varies from a single hydrogen atom to a long carbon chain. Two amino acids are joined by a dehydration reaction, in which a hydrogen atom is removed from an amino group on one molecule, and a hydroxyl group (–OH) is removed from the carboxylic-acid end of the other molecule to form water, H2O. This reaction results in the formation of a peptide bond, which joins two amino acids to form a dipeptide. Multiple peptide units can be linked to form longer peptide chains called polypeptides. A protein consists of one or more polypeptide chains, which are folded and coiled into a specific shape.

img.alt: Figure 5: Structure of an amino acid

pageData.subTitle: Nucleic Acid
pageData.text: are responsible for transmitting genetic information. The that form the links of a nucleic-acid chain are called . Each nucleotide has three parts: a pentose (five-carbon) sugar, a phosphate group, and a nitrogenous base. The nucleotides are connected to one other by phosphate-to-sugar , which form the backbone of the chain. The nitrogenous bases of each nucleotide are connected at right angles to the sugar molecule. These repeating nucleotides form a nucleic acid. See Figure 7.

, which is named for the five-carbon sugar, deoxyribose, is one type of nucleic acid. Two DNA strands form a double helix, which can be compared to a twisting ladder. The rungs of the ladder form from the pairing of sideways bases in each strand. The nitrogenous bases form a , which is a strong bond between hydrogen and nitrogen or oxygen that hold the two strands together. DNA can contain one of four nitrogen bases. Adenine and guanine (called purines) have two rings each, and cytosine and thymine (called pyrimidines) have one ring each. Adenine and thymine form two hydrogen bonds. Guanine and cytosine form three hydrogen bonds. Therefore, adenine and thymine always pair with each other, as do guanine and cytosine.

<button class='glossary-text'>Ribonucleic acid (RNA)</button> is single-stranded and is involved in <button class='glossary-text'>protein</button> synthesis. The sugar of RNA is a five-carbon pentose sugar called ribose. In RNA, the nitrogenous base thymine is replaced by uracil, which can form two hydrogen bonds.

<button class='glossary-text'>Adenosine triphosphate (ATP)</button> is a nucleic acid that has three phosphates bonded to one another. This is an unstable molecule. Disruption of the bond connecting the second and third phosphate causes a large amount of energy to be released and adenosine diphosphate (ADP) to be formed. ADP is much more stable than ATP. The energy released during this reaction drives most cellular processes that require energy, including active transport, motility, and cellular division. ATP is formed from ADP during cellular respiration.

pageData.question: The nucleic acid deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) consists of two strands of nucleotides arranged as a twisted ladder, also called a double helix. Which of the following best describes the chemical bonds that hold a DNA molecule together?

options.text: Phosphate-to-sugar covalent bonds form each strand; hydrogen bonds form the ladder.
Hydrogen bonds form each strand; ionic bonds form the ladder.
Nitrogenous base-to-sugar covalent bonds form each strand; hydrogen bonds form the ladder.
Phosphate-to-sugar covalent bonds form each strand; glycosidic bonds form the ladder.
Peptide bonds form each strand; covalent double bonds form the ladder.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The nucleotides in each strand are bonded to one another by phosphate-to-sugar covalent bonds. The nucleotides that complement each other across the molecule to form the rungs of the twisted ladder are attracted to each other by hydrogen bonds.

pageData.question: The covalent bond that connects two nucleotides together in a chain is between what components of the adjacent nucleotides?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The nucleotides in a nucleic acid strand are bonded to one another by phosphate-to-sugar covalent bonds.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Nucleic acids, such as deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) and ribonucleic acid (RNA), are made up of chains of monomers called nucleotides. Each nucleotide consists of three components – a five-carbon sugar, a phosphate group, and a nitrogenous base. DNA and RNA differ from one another in part because of the structure of the sugars and nitrogenous bases found in each molecule. To form the nucleotide chains, the phosphate group of one monomer is covalently bonded to the sugar of another monomer. RNA molecules consist of only one such nucleotide chain, or strand. DNA molecules, however, consist of two strands. These strands are arranged parallel to one another with the nitrogenous bases facing inward, forming hydrogen bonds across the molecule that roughly resemble rungs on a ladder.

img.alt: The chemical structure of a section of a DNA molecule.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Nucleic acids, such as deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) and ribonucleic acid (RNA), are made up of chains of monomers called nucleotides. Each nucleotide consists of three components – a five-carbon sugar, a phosphate group, and a nitrogenous base. DNA and RNA differ from one another in part because of the structure of the sugars and nitrogenous bases found in each molecule. To form the nucleotide chains, the phosphate group of one monomer is covalently bonded to the sugar of another monomer. RNA molecules consist of only one such nucleotide chain, or strand. DNA molecules, however, consist of two strands. These strands are arranged parallel to one another with the nitrogenous bases facing inward, forming hydrogen bonds across the molecule that roughly resemble rungs on a ladder.

img.alt: The chemical structure of a section of a DNA molecule.

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for Activities 1-2 of this investigation. Prepare by organizing the pieces of the molecular model kit. In Activity 1, you will build a simple hydrocarbon model, a saturated hydrocarbon model, unsaturated hydrocarbon models, and a cyclic hydrocarbon model. These will be disassembled before starting Activity 2. In Activity 2, you will build an open-chain glucose model, which you will transform into a cyclic glucose. You will build a total of 2 cyclic glucose models.  Then, you will build a maltose model. Next, transform 1 of the glucose models into a fructose model and build a sucrose model. Finally, disassemble the models.

A map describing the procedural workflow for Activities 3-5 of this investigation. In Activity 3, you will build a stearic acid model. Then, you will transform the lipid model into an oleic acid model, and then transform it into a linolenic acid model. Next, disassemble the model and build a triglyceride molecule. Finally, disassemble the model.  In Activity 4, you will build 4 different amino acid models, then build a polypeptide model. Finish the activity by disassembling the model.    In Activity 5build 2 complementary nucleotide models. Then, arrange the models into a DNA model. Next, transform the DNA model into an RNA model. Then, transform the nucleotide model into an ATP model. Finally, disassemble the models.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following sets of functional groups best describes the general structure of all amino acids?
Which of the following molecules catalyzes chemical reactions in living things?
Which of the following molecules would be considered a polysaccharide?
Which of the following is NOT a characteristic that distinguishes ribonucleic acid (RNA) from deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA)?

options.text: An RNA strand is held together by covalent double bonds.
The nucleotide uracil is present in RNA.
RNA molecules are directly involved in protein synthesis.
An RNA nucleotide contains a five-carbon ribose sugar.

assestmentData.question: The breakdown of a polysaccharide into its monosaccharide monomers would produce which of the following byproducts?
Which of the following best describes the structural difference between saturated fat and unsaturated fat?

options.text: Saturated fats have fatty acid chains without double bonds.
Saturated fats have fatty acid chains with triple bonds.
Saturated fats have more than three fatty acid chains.
Saturated fats have less than three fatty acid chains.
Saturated fats have more than one glycerol.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the overall structure of a polymer?

options.text: a series of repeating monomers bonded together
a long chain of carbon atoms bonded covalently to hydrogen atoms
two monomers linked by ionic bonds
a long chain of carbon atoms with one or more functional groups

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is a safety concern in this laboratory investigation?

options.text: The kit contains small parts that are a choking hazard for pets and children.
Glass could break; broken glass should not be picked up with your hands.
Some chemicals give off fumes; use chemicals in a well-ventilated room.
Household bleach is a corrosive chemical.
There are no safety concerns in this investigation.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following characteristics of an organic molecule is most responsible for its chemical reactivity?

options.text: the number of monomers in a polymer
the location of any double and triple bonds

assestmentData.question: Adenosine triphosphate (ATP), the molecule which provides the energy to drive certain cellular processes, is categorized as what type of macromolecule?

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Obtain all materials.
Open both of the molecular model kits. Sort the components of each molecular model kit.
Place the white hydrogen atoms in one compartment of the Y-plate Petri dish.
Place the black carbon atoms in a second compartment of the Y-plate Petri dish, and place the red oxygen atoms in the third compartment.
Sort the blue nitrogen atoms and the purple phosphate atoms into separate compartments of the second Y-plate Petri dish.
Place the white pieces of tubing, which represent , into the lids of the Petri dishes.

Two-dimensional structural formulas are presented in this manual. A three-dimensional molecular model may look different than the corresponding structural formula. A structural formula shows how atoms are bonded together in two dimensions but does not exactly replicate the complete model.
In Activity 1, you will model <button class='glossary-text'>hydrocarbons</button>. You will create four different hydrocarbon models: simple, saturated, unsaturated, and cyclic.

Examine a black piece from the molecular modeling kit. This black piece represents a carbon atom and has four projections. Each projection represents an outer-shell valence electron. To become stable, carbon needs four additional electrons to create a full outer shell of eight valence electrons.

Examine a white piece from the molecular modeling kit. This white piece represents a hydrogen atom and has one projection. The projection represents one valence electron. Hydrogen atoms have one electron shell and are stable with only two electrons.

Attach a hydrogen atom to one end of a white tube, which represents a . Attach the other end of the white tube to one of the four projections on the carbon atom. On paper, this bond is represented with a dash as shown here: C – H.
Repeat the previous step for the remaining projections on the carbon atom.
Label the model as methane, and take a photograph of the model for the Lab Notebook.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>

Methane is the simplest found in nature. On paper, the methane molecule is drawn with the carbon atom in the center and four hydrogen atoms surrounding it as shown in Figure 8. This formula is called a structural formula, because it shows the arrangement of each atom. A molecular formula shows only the number of atoms present. Methane has a molecular formula of CH4.

typeBefore.title: Propane — A Saturated Hydrocarbon
typeBefore.text: Carbon can also form single bonds with other carbon atoms to form long chains of hydrocarbons. These molecules are called saturated hydrocarbons, because all of the carbon atoms are connected by single bonds. The structural formula for propane is shown in Figure 9.

pageData.text: To build the propane molecule, C<sub>3</sub>H<sub>8</sub>, disconnect one hydrogen atom from the covalent bond of the methane molecule. Wrap a piece of masking or labeling tape around the covalent bond near the carbon atom (carbon #1), and label it “1” with a permanent marker.
Add a carbon atom (carbon #2) to the end of the labeled covalent bond. Add a covalent bond to carbon #2, and label it near the carbon atom.
Add a carbon atom (carbon #3) to the end of the labeled covalent bond. Add a covalent bond to carbon #3, and label it near the carbon atom.
Connect two more covalent bonds to carbon #2 and three covalent bonds on carbon #3. Add white hydrogen atoms to each covalent bond.
Carbons #1 and #3 should have three hydrogen atoms attached. Carbon #2 should have two hydrogen atoms attached.

Label the model as propane, and take a photograph for the Lab Notebook. <span class='bodyParaLineBreak'><span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>Although structural formulas show all of the atoms in a molecule, they do not always show the proper geometry. The three-dimensional model should show a tetrahedral arrangement with bond angles of 109° around all three carbon atoms in propane. This geometry results in a bent carbon chain rather than the linear one shown by the structural formula. Notice that every carbon atom is surrounded by four covalent bonds and has eight electrons.

typeBefore.title: Ethene and Ethyne — Unsaturated Hydrocarbons
typeBefore.text: Carbon can form compounds composed of chains with double and triple covalent bonds. These molecules are called unsaturated hydrocarbons, because some carbon atoms are not connected by single bonds.

pageData.text: To create a double bond, attach white tubes to two projections of a carbon atom. Attach these two tubes (covalent bonds) to a second carbon atom. This creates a double bond between the two carbon atoms. Two openings remain on each carbon atom for two additional covalent bonds. To model ethene, attach a hydrogen atom to each of the vacant spaces on both carbon atoms.

To model ethyne, attach white tubes to three of the projections on the carbon atom. All three white tubes may be difficult to attach to the second carbon atom; they may bend, but it is possible to attach them.
Build compounds with the molecular formulas C2H4 and C2H2. The models should resemble the structural formulas shown in Figure 10.

pageData.altText: Figure 10: Model of ethene, Model of ethyne

pageData.text: Label the models by name, and photograph them for the Lab Notebook.

typeBefore.title: Benzene — A Cyclic Hydrocarbon
typeBefore.text: Carbon can also form ring-structured compounds. Benzene is a hydrocarbon ring that is commonly found in nature. This compound is a hexagonal ring with alternating double and single covalent bonds between carbon atoms.

pageData.text: Build a model of benzene, C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>6</sub>. Note in Figure 11 that each of the six carbon atoms has four covalent bonds: one double bond with another carbon, one single bond with a carbon, and one single bond with a hydrogen.
Label the model as benzene, and take a photograph for the Lab Notebook.
Remove the pieces of labeling tape from the covalent bonds.
Disassemble the molecular models, and return the model parts to the appropriate compartments of the Y-plate Petri dishes.

In Activity 2, you will model <button class='glossary-text'>carbohydrates</button>. You will start creating an open chain glucose molecule, which you will transform into a cyclical glucose molecule. You will then use and modify these two <button class='glossary-text'>monosaccharide</button> models to create different types of monosaccharides and disaccharides.
Connect a carbon atom to a <button class='glossary-text'>covalent bond</button>.
Wrap a piece of labeling tape around the covalent bond near the carbon atom (carbon #1), and label it “1” with a permanent marker.
Add a carbon atom (carbon #2) to the end of the labeled covalent bond. Add a covalent bond to carbon #2, and label it near the carbon atom.
Repeat the preceding step for four additional carbon atoms (carbons #3 through #6).
Attach an oxygen atom to the first carbon atom, carbon #1, using two bonds (a double bond).
Form five –OH groups by attaching one hydrogen atom to each of five oxygen atoms.
Attach the five –OH groups to the carbon chain in the positions indicated in Figure 12.

Attach hydrogen atoms to the empty spaces in the carbon chain as shown in Figure 12. <span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>This is a model of an open-chain glucose molecule. Seven hydrogens should be added to complete the glucose molecule.
Label the model, and take a photograph for the Lab Notebook.
To demonstrate the cyclic structure of glucose, carefully twist the carbon chain to bring together carbon #1 and carbon #5 as shown in Figure 13.
Detach one bond from the oxygen atom connected to carbon #1, but leave the bond attached to the carbon atom. This represents breaking the carbon-oxygen double bond but keeping the single bond.
Remove the hydrogen from the –OH group of carbon #5, and attach the hydrogen to the oxygen of carbon #1.
Attach the oxygen of carbon #5 to carbon #1 to complete the ring as shown in Figure 14. Carbon #1 will now have two carbon-oxygen single bonds.
Repeat steps 1–13 to build a second glucose molecule.
Bring together the –OH group attached to carbon #1 of one glucose molecule with the –OH group attached to carbon #4 of the other glucose molecule.
Remove the entire –OH group from one glucose molecule and the hydrogen atom from the –OH group of the other glucose molecule to form a molecule of water (H<sub>2</sub>O).
Connect the red oxygen (remaining from the disrupted –OH group) to the carbon as shown in Figure 15. This new molecule is the disaccharide maltose.
Label the model as maltose, and take a photograph for the Lab Notebook.
Remove the oxygen atom that is connecting the two <button class='glossary-text'>monosaccharides</button> in maltose. Attach an –OH group with an open bond to carbon #1 of the glucose molecule.
Attach an –OH group to carbon #4 of the other glucose molecule. Both glucose molecules should be identical (as they were in step 14).
One of the two glucose molecules will be restructured to build fructose. Set the other glucose model aside.
Remove one hydrogen atom from carbon #2.
Locate the oxygen molecule in the six-membered ring that bridges carbon #1 to carbon #5. Disconnect the oxygen molecule from carbon #1 and attach it to carbon #2.
Connect the hydrogen (removed from carbon #2) to carbon #1. Compare the resulting molecule to that shown in Figure 16. How do they differ?
Label the molecule as fructose, and take a photograph for the Lab Notebook.

Sucrose requires one fructose and one glucose molecule. Turn the fructose model over so that carbon #2 is on the left side and carbon #5 is on the right side. Bring together the –OH group attached to carbon #1 of glucose and the –OH group attached to carbon #2 of fructose.
Remove the –OH group from one molecule and the hydrogen from the –OH group of the other to form a molecule of water (H<sub>2</sub>O).
Connect the oxygen (remaining from the disrupted –OH group) to the carbon as shown in Figure 17. The model formed in this step is the disaccharide sucrose, which is commonly known as table sugar.
Label the model, and take a photograph for the Lab Notebook.
Disassemble the molecular model, and return each piece to the corresponding compartment of the Y-plate Petri dish.

In Activity 3, you will model <button class='glossary-text'>lipids</button>. You will start by creating a stearic acid molecule, which you will transform into an oleic acid molecule, and then a linolenic acid molecule. You will then build three butyric acid molecules and a glycerol molecule, which you will combine to create a <button class='glossary-text'>triglyceride</button> molecule.
Attach two <button class='glossary-text'>covalent bonds</button> to an oxygen atom.
Connect both covalent bonds to a single carbon atom. This is a carbon-oxygen double bond.
Attach another covalent bond to the carbon atom. Wrap a piece of labeling tape around the covalent bond near the carbon atom (carbon #1), and label it “1” with a permanent marker.
Connect two covalent bonds to an oxygen atom. Attach a hydrogen atom to one of the covalent bonds. This is a hydroxyl (–OH) group.
Attach the hydroxyl (–OH) group to carbon #1 to form a carboxyl (–COOH) group.
Attach a chain of 17 carbon atoms and 17 covalent bonds to the carboxyl group. Label these carbon atoms 2–17 on the covalent bond near each carbon atom.

Add a covalent bond and hydrogen atom to each available space on the carbon chain. <span class='bodyParaLineBreak'> Carbons #2 through #16 will each be attached to two hydrogen atoms. Carbon #17 will be attached to three hydrogen atoms. This molecule is stearic acid.
Label the model stearic acid, and take a photograph for the Lab Notebook.

typeBefore.title: Oleic Acid — A Fatty Acid

pageData.text: Remove one hydrogen atom from carbon #9. Remove one hydrogen atom and the covalent bond from carbon #10.
Use the remaining covalent bond on carbon #9 to attach carbon #10 with a double bond. This molecule is oleic acid.
Label the model oleic acid, and take a photograph for the Lab Notebook.

typeBefore.title: Linolenic Acid — A Fatty Acid

pageData.text: Starting with oleic acid, remove one hydrogen atom from carbon #12 and one hydrogen atom and the covalent bond from carbon #13. Connect these carbon atoms with a double bond. This will be the second carbon-carbon double bond in this molecule.

Repeat the preceding step with carbons #15 and #16 to create a third carbon-carbon double bond. The molecule is now linolenic acid, which is the major component of linseed oil. Label the model, and take a photograph for the Lab Notebook.
Remove the labeling tape from the covalent bonds.
Disassemble the molecular models, and return the pieces to the appropriate compartments of the Y-plate Petri dish.

typeBefore.title: Butyric Acid — A Fatty Acid

pageData.text: Build a four-carbon chain.
Add a carbon-oxygen double bond at carbon #1.
Add an –OH group to carbon #1 to create a carboxyl (–COOH) group.
Add hydrogen to each free space on the other three carbons. This molecule is butyric acid (see Figure 18).
Build two more butyric acid molecules.
Examine the structural formula for glycerol shown in Figure 19. Build a model of the glycerol molecule.
The three molecules of butyric acid will be attached to the glycerol molecule.

First, remove a hydroxide group from each butyric acid and a hydrogen atom from each of the hydroxide groups on the glycerol. These atoms can be combined to form three molecules of water (one hydrogen atom attached to each hydroxide group).

Attach the oxygen on the glycerol to the carbon atom on the butyric acid molecule.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>Carbon #1 on the butyric acid has a carbon-oxygen double bond and a carbon-oxygen single bond that attaches to glycerol.
Repeat for the other two molecules of butyric acid.
This molecule is glycerol tributyrate, which is a simple . Notice that each carboxyl group connects to a hydroxyl group in glycerol as indicated in Figure 20.
Label the model, and take a photograph for the Lab Notebook.
Disassemble the molecular model, and return the pieces to the appropriate compartments of the Y-plate Petri dish.

In Activity 4, you will model amino acids and polypeptides. You will start by creating four different amino acid molecules, then combining three amino acids via <button class='glossary-text'>peptide bonds</button> to create a polypeptide.
Attach three hydrogen atoms to a nitrogen atom. This is a model of an ammonia molecule.
Remove one hydrogen atom. The remaining group of atoms, –NH<sub>2</sub>, is the amino group.
Use two <button class='glossary-text'>covalent bonds</button> to create a double bond between an oxygen atom and a carbon atom.
Attach an –OH group to the carbon atom. This is the carboxyl group.
Attach the carboxyl (–COOH) and amino (–NH<sub>2</sub>) groups and one hydrogen atom to a carbon atom as shown in Figure 21.

pageData.altText: Figure 21: Model of an amino acid

pageData.text: Attach a hydrogen atom in place of the “R” that is shown in Figure 21. This is glycine, which is the simplest amino acid. Compare the model to the structure shown in Figure 22.
Label the model, and take a photograph for the Lab Notebook.

typeBefore.title: Alanine, Valine, and Glutamic Acid — Aminio Acids

pageData.text: Figure 23 shows three more amino acids. Notice that the structures are similar to the basic structure of an amino acid shown in Figure 21. Build a molecular model of each of these amino acids.

Bring together the carboxyl end of one amino acid and the amino end of another. Join the two ends by removing a molecule of water (–OH from the carboxyl group and –H from the amino group) and attaching carbon to nitrogen. The resulting molecule is a dipeptide.
Repeat steps 9–10 to attach a third amino acid to the dipeptide. This molecule is a polypeptide.
Long peptide strands can be twisted and folded to make a <button class='glossary-text'>protein</button>.
Label the molecule as “polypeptide,” and take a photograph for  the Lab Notebook.
Disassemble the molecular model, and return the pieces to the appropriate compartments of the Y-plate Petri dishes.

In Activity 5, you will model <button class='glossary-text'>nucleic acids</button>. You will create a thymine <button class='glossary-text'>nucleotide</button> and an adenine nucleotide, which you will align to identify the <button class='glossary-text'>hydrogen bonds</button> in a <button class='glossary-text'>DNA</button> helix. You will then modify the DNA nucleotides into <button class='glossary-text'>RNA</button> nucleotides. You will conclude the activity by taking the RNA adenine molecule and transforming it into <button class='glossary-text'>adenosine triphosphate (ATP)</button>.

Use two <button class='glossary-text'>covalent bonds</button> to form a double bond between oxygen and a purple phosphorous atom. Attach three additional oxygen molecules to the phosphorous with single covalent bonds. This is a model of a phosphate group (PO<sub>4</sub><sup>–3</sup>).

Refer to Figure 24 to build the pentose sugar of one <button class='glossary-text'>DNA</button> <button class='glossary-text'>nucleotide</button>. Label carbons #1–5 as shown. Note that carbon #1 is connected to the right of the oxygen atom at the tip of the ring. Leave one peg open on carbon #1 to attach to the nitrogenous base.

pageData.altText: Figure 24: Model of pentose sugar of one DNA nucleotide

pageData.text: Build the nitrogenous base thymine by attaching an oxygen atom to a carbon atom with a double bond. Refer to Figure 25 to build this base.

pageData.altText: Figure 25: Model of nitrogenous base thymine

pageData.text: Attach the thymine ring to carbon #1 of the pentose molecule built in step 2.
Repeat steps 1 and 2 to form a second pentose sugar.
Build the nitrogenous base adenine by attaching a nitrogen atom to a carbon atom with a double bond. Refer to Figure 26 to build this nitrogenous base.

pageData.altText: Figure 26: Model of a nitrogenous base

pageData.text: To simulate how adenine and thymine form in the DNA helix, represented by the dotted lines in Figure 27, arrange adenine and thymine as shown in Figure 27.

pageData.altText: Figure 27: Model of arrangement of adenine and thymine

pageData.text: Label the model as DNA, and take a photograph for the Lab Notebook.

To modify the model of DNA to represent , replace the deoxyribose sugar on the adenine nucleotide with ribose. Replace the hydrogen on carbon #2 of the pentose sugar with a hydroxyl (–OH). Refer to Figure 28.
Replace the deoxyribose sugar on the thymine nucleotide with ribose by replacing hydrogen on carbon #2 of each pentose sugar with a hydroxyl group.
Thymine is not an RNA nucleotide. Convert thymine to uracil by removing the methyl (–CH3) group from thymine. Replace the methyl group with a hydrogen atom. See Figure 29.

pageData.altText: Figure 29: Model of an RNA nucleotide

pageData.text: Label the RNA nucleotides, and take a photograph for the Lab Notebook.

Save the model of adenine to build an <button class='glossary-text'>ATP</button> molecule in the next section. Disassemble the uracil RNA nucleotide, and return the pieces to the appropriate compartments of the Y-plate Petri dishes.
Use two covalent bonds to create a double bond between a red oxygen atom and a purple phosphorous atom.
Attach three covalent bonds to the remaining projections on the phosphorous atom.
Attach oxygen atoms to three of the covalent bonds to form a phosphate.
Attach a covalent bond to one of the oxygen atoms. To this covalent bond add a purple phosphorous atom.
Attach one oxygen atom to the second phosphorus atom with an oxygen-phosphorus double bond. Attach the second oxygen atom to the phosphorus atom with an oxygen-phosphorus single bond.
Assemble an ATP molecule from the adenosine RNA nucleotide and the double phosphate as shown in Figure 30.

pageData.altText: Figure 30: Model of an ATP molecule

pageData.text: Label the molecule as ATP, and take a photograph for the Lab Notebook.
Remove labeling tape from the covalent bonds.
Disassemble the molecular model, and return all of the pieces to the appropriate compartments of the Y-plate Petri dishes.

text: Remove the pieces of labeling tape from the <button class='glossary-text'>covalent bonds</button>.
Disassemble the molecular models, and return the model parts to the appropriate compartments of the Y-plate Petri dishes.

pageData.content: Figure 7. A chain of deoxyribonucleotides and their parts

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for Activities 1-2 of this investigation. Prepare by organizing the pieces of the molecular model kit. In Activity 1, you will build a simple hydrocarbon model, a saturated hydrocarbon model, unsaturated hydrocarbon models, and a cyclic hydrocarbon model. These will be disassembled before starting Activity 2. In Activity 2, you will build an open-chain glucose model, which you will transform into a cyclic glucose. You will build a total of 2 cyclic glucose models. Then, you will build a maltose model. Next, transform 1 of the glucose models into a fructose model and build a sucrose model. Finally, disassemble the models.

A map describing the procedural workflow for Activities 3-5 of this investigation. In Activity 3, you will build a stearic acid model. Then, you will transform the lipid model into an oleic acid model, and then transform it into a linolenic acid model. Next, disassemble the model and build a triglyceride molecule. Finally, disassemble the model. In Activity 4, you will build 4 different amino acid models, then build a polypeptide model. Finish the activity by disassembling the model. In Activity 5build 2 complementary nucleotide models. Then, arrange the models into a DNA model. Next, transform the DNA model into an RNA model. Then, transform the nucleotide model into an ATP model. Finally, disassemble the models.
Figure 10: Model of ethene, Model of ethyne
Figure 21: Model of an amino acid

Figure 23. Alanine, valine and glutamine molecules

Figure 27: Model of arrangement of adenine and thymine

Figure 30: Model of an ATP molecule

data.title: Adenosine triphosphate (ATP)
data.content: A type of nucleic acid that functions as the main energy currency of a cell

data.title: Carbohydrate
data.content: A class of macromolecule composed of chemical compounds that have an empirical formula (simplest whole-number ratio of atoms) of CH<sub>2</sub>O, which indicates a ratio of 1:2:1 for carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen, respectively

data.title: Covalent bond
data.content: A chemical bond in which there is a  sharing of an electron pair between two atoms

data.title: Dehydrogenation
data.content: The process of removing hydrogen

data.title: Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA)
data.content: A type of nucleic acid composed of nucleotides containing the five-carbon sugar deoxyribose; it is usually double-stranded

data.title: Hydrocarbon
data.content: An organic chemical compound that consists of only of the elements carbon and hydrogen

data.title: Hydrogen bond
data.content: A bond formed between an electropositive atom, usually hydrogen, and a strongly electronegative atom, such as oxygen or nitrogen

data.title: Lipid
data.content: Most structurally diverse class of macromolecule; examples of this type of molecule include fats, oils, waxes, sterols, and phospholipids

data.title: Monomer
data.content: The individual unit of a polymer

data.title: Monosaccharide
data.content: The monomer of complex carbohydrates; the least complex of the carbohydrate molecules and is often called a “simple sugar”

data.title: Nucleic acid
data.content: A class of macromolecule composed of monomers called nucleotides; examples of this type of molecule include deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) and ribonucleic acid (RNA)

data.title: Nucleotide
data.content: The monomer of nucleic acids; it has three parts - a pentose (five-carbon) sugar, a phosphate group, and a nitrogenous base

data.title: Peptide bond
data.content: A chemical bond formed between two molecules when the carboxyl group of one molecule reacts with the amino group of the other molecule

data.title: Polymer
data.content: A large number of similar units (monomers) bonded together to form a large molecule; also called a macromolecule

data.title: Polymerization
data.content: The process of reacting monomer molecules together in a chemical reaction to form polymer chains

data.title: Polysaccharide
data.content: The most complex of carbohydrates comprised of several monosaccharides linked in various configurations

data.title: Polyunsaturated fatty acid
data.content: A type of fatty acid that has two or more double bonds in its carbon chain and therefore fewer hydrogen atoms

data.title: Protein
data.content: A class of macromolecule composed of complex organic compounds made up of monomers called amino acids

data.title: Ribonucleic acid (RNA)
data.content: A type of nucleic acid composed of nucleotides containing the five-carbon sugar ribose; it is usually single-stranded

data.title: Saturated fatty acid
data.content: A type of fatty acid composed entirely of carbon atoms joined by single covalent bonds

data.title: Triglyceride
data.content: A type of lipid that contains three fatty acid chains bonded to a glycerol molecule (a sugar alcohol)

data.title: Unsaturated fatty acid
data.content: A type of fatty acid composed of one or more double bonds in its carbon chain, therefore it has two-fewer hydrogen atoms per double bond
